bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Domingo F. Ramos, March 6, 1941

div1.p: Truby supports Hench's efforts to establish a memorial at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Domingo F. Ramos, March 6, 1941
div1.opener:
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
March 6, 1941
His Excellency,
Dr. Domingo Ramos,
Minister of National Defense,
Government of Cuba.
(Through Dr. P. S. Hench).
Your Excellency:
div1.p:
I have carefully reviewed the documentary summary
prepared by Dr. Philip S. Hench regarding the historical sites of
“Camp Lazear” and the Columbia Barracks Yellow Fever Hospital (1900).
As I was on duty at the Columbia Barracks Hospital from August 17,
1899 until November 30, 1900 (with the exception of a short period
in the Summer of 1900), I am thoroughly familiar with the location
of those sites and with what transpired there while the Reed Board
was conducting its yellow fever experiments.

I made several trips to Camp Lazear with Major Reed
while the camp was being constructed and am thoroughly familiar with
its location on the “San Jose Farm” owned at the time by Señor Rojas.
Dr. Hench has positively located it and, from his description of the
old building occupied by Señor Zunzunegui, I feel quite certain that
he has definitely located the “Infected Clothing Building” used in
the yellow fever experiments in 1900.

Major Reed occupied the two rooms adjacent to mine
in the doctors' quarters at the hospital and, as I was the Commanding
Officer of the hospital (during September, October and November 1900),
I was called upon by Major Reed for much assistance in the way of
personnel, medical supplies and equipment for Camp Lazear.

Dr. Roger Post Ames was serving directly under me
at that time and had charge of our yellow fever wards near the South-
western borders of the hospital grounds.

The deep cut of the La Playa railroad, running in a
Northwesterly direction through the hospital grounds, made the far
side of this excavation an excellent place for isolating and treating
yellow fever cases. It was used for that purpose during all the time
I was there. Dr. Hench has very exactly shown this location on the
maps and in other data he has presented. Major J. R. Kean, Dr.
Carroll and many others were treated there. Dr. Jesse W. Lazear
died there.

It gives me much pleasure therefore to give you,
for the information of the Cuban Government, the facts regarding
this matter. I am also pleased to help Dr. Hench in his worthy
efforts to assist you in establishing a fitting memorial to the
great men whose discoveries did so much for Cuba and the rest of
the world. If I can be of further assistance in any way, I am
at your service.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, Albert E. Truby ALBERT E. TRUBY
Brigadier General, U. S. Army (Medical Corps)
Retired
